text: a few years ago there was a great
cartoon I think in the New Yorker where
you see some native people on the shore
and out in the harbor come the big tall
ships and uh one Native American says to
the other I knew that immigration policy
was something we had to work on um and
that's a little bit of a humorous
approach but my first year in teaching
in Arizona where I grew up I was
teaching at Arizona State the course
immigration law and there were Native
American students in the class and they
seriously asked all of us and taught me
to
re-evaluate the myths we tell ourselves
about immigration law we often talk
about the United States being this open
territory where everyone was free to
come where the land was ours for
developing and we forget that uh even at
the time of the founding of our country
and the first Western Europeans coming
to the United States there were
negotiations with existing people and
there were should we call them bilateral
treaties of negotiation about who could
live here and who
couldn't then I think another aspect of
it is we often think
of uh our immigration history is two or
three paragraphs in our eighth grade
civics book you know first came Columbus
and his ships then came the pilgrims and
each story of uh the first European
settlers the United States has with it
aspects of immigration limitation um so
for example people coming with the
Puritans were not anyone who wanted to
come there was an application process
people had to qualify uh they had to be
selected through the theoc Theocratic
leaders of the Puritans and their
religious community and if you didn't
uh come with the original Puritan group
and you wanted to join later perhaps you
were living in uh Rhode Island and you
wanted to become part of the Puritan
communities in Massachusetts you had to
apply and be vetted and qualified much
as we do with immigrants today so uh
tensions quickly Rose in those early
religious communities about people who
were maybe the second generation not
quite as committed to the Puritan way of
life or the mercantilism that was
growing in the Boston area and other
parts of New England that was changing
the migration patterns and so there's
always been debates about who we going
to let live next door who qualifies to
come again when we say we're talking
about immigration and the Industrial
Revolution and the agricultural
revolutions before often the story is
told as just the migration of the Free
Labor the free white male or the uh
people who could come of course part of
all immigration history in the United
States is also forced migration slavery
and uh people um subjugated uh to to
work here temporarily such as indentured
servants or the convicts Who were
settled briefly in the state of Georgia
uh but the Industrial Revolution coming
let's say post Civil War uh the the
birth of factories the greater need for
labor people moving off uh some of the
Farms um we begin to have denser
populations in cities and in increased
ability for ships to bring people from
Europe in a safer more economical method
so the great period of American rapid
immigration we think the Ellis Island
Experience right all the Europeans that
were coming the millions of people
coming at that period um we often think
of that as everyone was welcome it was
all positive uh sure people suffered in
steerage as they were doing the passage
but once they settled in Boston
or came to Chicago or uh found work in
Chinatown in San Francisco it was all
good um but actually there's always been
great tensions about all migration
populations and one of the sad stories
for in my view of our history is that
organized labor early on really took the
position that it was better to be
pro-immigration controls and
restriction uh rather than working to
organize the new immigrants coming and
the earliest most grie Grievous example
is organized labor in not today's unions
but the organized labor groups or
political groups of California opposing
Chinese migration and uh the California
delegates to Congress were successful in
passing our first complete uh
immigration ban the Chinese Exclusion
acts and there were several of them
between 1880 and 1890s But ultimately um
the motivations were rhetoric that you
hear today things like these people come
to this country but they don't want to
learn our language they don't integrate
into our society they don't go to church
they will live 10 men in a room in
conditions no civilized man would live
and work for wages that no honest
American would work for so so that's
often stories you hear today about
Chinese or you hear today about people
from Mexico and Central and South
America that it's an unfair competition
to American
labor so let's start with a proposition
that in any historical period of
migration whether we're talking about
the Irish coming in the 1830s to the
1860s we often say the Irish came in
response to the Potato Famine well we we
can do that as a shorthand as a
soundbite but the actual stories are
much more nuanced and in any American
economic history you'll know there are
boom and bus periods so we have the
growth of the railroads the growth of
factories but there's a huge recession
in 1893 there's a collapse of markets
again um later maybe the Spanish
American war of 1898
was uh in part complicated and necessary
by economic need uh Ellis Island's at
its peak in the first 10 to 20 years of
the 20th century so 1900 to 1920 we had
enormous recessions post World War I
around the world uh so when we think
today we think America's in a recession
some would say a depression the world's
in a recession uh we can't afford new
immigrants they'll take our jobs again
that's a story that has or a truth that
has been explored in Immigration policy
throughout the history of our country
and all countries
um it's I'm not an economist but uh like
any good law professor I can read the
economic literature and I can tell you
there arguments on any side so there are
economists who will say that actually
when you are in a
recession having relatively open Borders
or having the ability to bring in
labor and and make sure that labor is
paid Fair wages and we can have debates
about is that mean minimum wage or
higher adverse affected wage actually
creates economic employment opportunity
helps your country rebound from a period
of stagnation or economic depression um
they're similar to the
debates that many people make to argue
against a minimum wage they say a
minimum wage
actually um deters entrepreneurs from
investing because the capital risks are
too high uh I wouldn't go that far but I
do think there are many examples in
history where it is immigrants
industry and the willingness to start at
lower wages that has let industries
develop flourish and come back
